title: 107_hr3676
content: The Act titled "Medicare, Medicaid, and MCH Tobacco Use Cessation Promotion Act of 2001" amends the Medicare program to include coverage for counseling for tobacco cessation. This includes defining counseling for cessation of tobacco use as a covered service under the Act. The Act "Medicare, Medicaid, and MCH Tobacco Use Cessation Promotion Act of 2001" expands Medicare coverage to include counseling for tobacco cessation. Counseling for cessation of tobacco use is defined as diagnostic, therapy, and counseling services provided by healthcare professionals authorized under State law or designated by the Secretary. Services must align with clinical practice guidelines on treating tobacco use. The Act expands Medicare coverage to include counseling for tobacco cessation, aligning with clinical practice guidelines. Payment for counseling services will be 100 percent of the actual charge or the amount determined by a fee schedule established by the Secretary. The Act expands Medicare coverage to include counseling for tobacco cessation without deductibles or coinsurance in outpatient hospital settings. The amendments made by this section shall have an effective date. The amendments made by this section will apply to services provided on or after January 1 of the first calendar year that begins at least 6 months after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 3. COVERAGE OF COUNSELING FOR CESSATION OF TOBACCO USE UNDER THE MEDICAID PROGRAM. The Medicaid program is amending its coverage to include tobacco use cessation medications approved by the FDA and counseling for pregnant women to quit smoking. The Medicaid program is expanding coverage to include tobacco use cessation counseling for pregnant women without cost-sharing, effective from January 1 of the first calendar year that begins at least 6 months after the enactment of the Act. The Social Security Act is amended to include tobacco cessation counseling and medications as part of quality maternal and child health services. This amendment will take effect upon the enactment of the Act.
